THE IONOSPHERE OF MARS IS A PARTIALLY-IONIZED ATMOSPHERE WITH THE MAXIMUM ELECTRON DENSITY (NMAX) BEING LESS THAN ONE-MILLIONTH THE NEUTRAL DENSITY. SUCH A TENUOUS PLASMA RESULTS IN THE IONOSPHERE BEING A HIGHLY SENSITIVE SYSTEM RESPONSE FUNCTION TO THE BROAD SPECTRUM OF PHYSICAL PROCESSES THAT CREATE, MODIFY OR REMOVE PLASMA. THESE INCLUDE SOLAR-PRODUCTION, CHEMICAL LOSS, AND A HOST OF DYNAMICAL MECHANISMS (E.G., PLASMA DIFFUSION, NEUTRAL WIND-INDUCED MOTIONS, WAVE/TIDAL MOTIONS, UPWARD ESCAPE, AND SOLAR WIND CAPTURE). MOST OF THE IONOSPHERIC PLASMA AT MARS IS FOUND AT HEIGHTS ABOVE THE ALTITUDE OF NMAX (H>~130 KM) WHERE THE ELECTRON DENSITY DECREASES EXPONENTIALLY ULTIMATELY BEING SWEPT AWAY BY THE SOLAR WIND AT ~400 KM. THE NASA MAVEN MISSION WILL STUDY ATMOSPHERIC ESCAPE AND FUNDAMENTAL TO THAT PROCESS IS THE REMOVAL OF THE TOPSIDE IONOSPHERE. THE PARAMETER THAT DESCRIBES THE FULL INVENTORY OF IONOSPHERIC PLASMA IS CALLED THE TOTAL ELECTRON CONTENT (TEC), DEFINED AS THE INTEGRAL OF THE ELECTRON DENSITY PROFILE, TEC = INTEGRAL NE(H) DH. MAVEN WILL NOT MEASURE TEC VALUES, BUT RATHER THE ELECTRON AND ION DENSITIES AT HEIGHTS ALONG ITS ELLIPTICAL ORBIT. PLACING MAVEN OBSERVATIONS INTO THE CONTEXT OF GLOBAL TEC PATTERNS BOTH ADVANCES MAVEN SCIENCE YIELD AND SERVES AS VALIDATIONS OF HOW TEC CAN BE CHARACTERIZED. TWO SATELLITES CURRENTLY IN ORBIT AROUND MARS MAKE TEC OBSERVATIONS NASA S SHARAD SYSTEM ONBOARD THE MARS RECONNAISSANCE ORBITER (MRO) AND ESA S MARSIS INSTRUMENT ON THE MARS EXPRESS (MEX) SATELLITE. IN BOTH CASES, TEC IS COMPUTED AS A CORRECTION TERM FOR RADAR POSITIONAL INFORMATION OF SURFACE AND SUB-SURFACE TARGETS. THE RADAR RADIO WAVES ARE AFFECTED BY THE TEC ALONG THE DOWNWARD AND RETURN RAY-PATHS, WITH SIGNAL RETARDATION GIVING AN ERROR TO RANGE VALUES. GIVEN THAT THE IONOSPHERE CHANGES WITH SOLAR ZENITH ANGLE, LATITUDE AND SOLAR CONDITIONS, EACH AND EVERY RADAR SIGNAL HAS TO BE CORRECTED FOR THE IONOSPHERE ENCOUNTERED. THESE RANGE ERROR CORRECTIONS TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT FOR CORRECT GEOLOGICAL STUDIES BECOME A VALUABLE DATABASE TO IONOSPHERIC RESEARCHERS. THIS PROPOSAL OFFERS A WAY TO USE THE REMARKABLY LARGE DATABASES OF TEC DATA THAT ARE ARCHIVED ON THE NASA PDS SYSTEM FROM THE MRO S SHARAD RADAR EXPERIMENT, AND THE EUROPEAN SPACE AGENCY S PUBLIC ARCHIVE FOR THE MARS EXPRESS MARSIS EXPERIMENT. PILOT STUDIES USING SUCH DATA HAVE BEEN PUBLISHED BY THE PI AND HIS COLLEAGUES, AND THE PROPOSED INVESTIGATIONS WILL BUILD UPON THESE EXPERIENCES USING THE FAR LARGER DATA SETS NOW AVAILABLE. PARTICULAR ATTENTION WILL BE GIVEN TO (1) OBSERVATIONS ABOVE REGIONS WITH STRONG CRUSTAL MAGNETIC FIELDS, AND (2) DAYS WHEN BOTH SATELLITES (MRO AND MEX) MAKE OBSERVATION ABOVE DIFFERENT LOCATIONS ON THE PLANET.

doc.ContractDescription: THE PROPOSED INVESTIGATION ADDRESSES THE ISSUE OF THE MECHANISM(S) OF CORONAL HEATING IN ACTIVE REGION LOOPS BY EXPLOITING THE NEW AND UNIQUE DIAGNOSTICS PROVIDED BY THE INTERFACE REGION IMAGING SPECTROGRAPH (IRIS). WE FOCUS ON SMALL SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALE MOSS BRIGHTENINGS, WHICH OFFER A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO INVESTIGATE THE CHARACTERISTIC OF CORONAL ENERGY RELEASE, THE RESPONSE OF THE PLASMA TO VERY IMPULSIVE HEATING EVENTS, AND THE ROLE OF PARTICLE ACCELERATION IN ACTIVE REGION HEATING. THE IRIS TRANSITION REGION AND CHROMOSPHERIC OBSERVATIONS AT HIGH SPATIAL, SPECTRAL AND TEMPORAL RESOLUTION, PROVIDE UNPRECEDENTED DETAILED PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS THAT ALLOW TO DETERMINE THE FINE SPATIAL AND THERMAL STRUCTURING OF THE PLASMA AT THE BASE OF CORONAL LOOPS, AND ITS DYNAMICS THROUGH DOPPLER SHIFTS AND LINE PROFILES. THE PLASMA IN THE TRANSITION REGION AND CHROMOSPHERE OF IMPULSIVELY HEATED LOOPS IS EXTREMELY SENSITIVE TO THE PROPERTIES OF THE HEATING (E.G., TOTAL ENERGY RELEASE, DURATION OF HEAT PULSES), AND ITS DYNAMICS PROVIDE FUNDAMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS FOR THE HEATING PROCESSES (E.G., NON-THERMAL ELECTRON BEAM HEATING VS. CONDUCTION). PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS OF IRIS OBSERVATIONS OF MOSS VARIABILITY STRONGLY SUGGESTS THAT THE CHROMOSPHERIC LINES IN PARTICULAR, HAVE CRUCIAL DIAGNOSTIC POTENTIAL TO DISTINGUISH DIFFERENT HEATING MECHANISMS. THEREFORE, THE INTERPRETATION OF THESE IRIS OBSERVATIONS REQUIRES THE USE OF STATE-OF- THE-ART MODELS INCLUDING NON-LTE RADIATIVE TRANSFER FOR A PROPER TREATMENT OF THE CHROMOSPHERE. WE WILL USE THE RADYN RADIATIVE- HYDRODYNAMIC LOOP MODEL (CARLSSON&STEIN 1997, LNP, 489,159; ALLRED ET AL. 2006, APJ, 644, 484), WHICH MEETS THIS REQUIREMENT AND ALSO ALLOWS TO MODEL HEATING BY NON-THERMAL ELECTRON BEAMS. BY COMPARING DIRECTLY, IN A QUANTITATIVE FASHION, THE OBSERVATIONS WITH THE PREDICTIONS OF MODELS OF IMPULSIVELY HEATED LOOPS - BOTH WITH AND WITHOUT BEAM HEATING - WE WILL BE ABLE TO INVESTIGATE THE ROLE OF BEAM HEATING IN THE ENERGETICS OF NON-FLARING ACTIVE REGION PLASMA, AND THE CONDITIONS LEADING TO EVENTS IN WHICH BEAM HEATING OCCURS. IRIS OBSERVATIONS OF THE RAPID MOSS VARIABILITY PUT VERY TIGHT CONSTRAINTS ON THE MODELS THEREFORE PROVIDING THE OPPORTUNITY TO MAKE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS IN UNDERSTANDING ENERGY RELEASE, MECHANISMS OF ENERGY TRANSPORT, AND DYNAMIC PLASMA PROCESSES. THE PROPOSED INVESTIGATION IS THEREFORE MAXIMIZING THE SCIENCE POTENTIAL OF IRIS, FULLY TAKING ADVANTAGE OF ITS CAPABILITIES OF SPATIAL, TEMPORAL AND SPECTRAL RESOLUTION, AND USING ITS DATA AS A UNIQUE TOOL FOR UNDERSTANDING CORONAL HEATING DESPITE OBSERVING NON-CORONAL PLASMA. OUR PROPOSED INVESTIGATION IS HIGHLY RELEVANT TO FIRST TWO QUESTIONS OF THIS IRIS GI PROGRAM, CONCERNING THE TYPES OF NON-THERMAL ENERGY DOMINATING IN THE CHROMOSPHERE AND BEYOND, AND THE FLOW OF MASS AND ENERGY FROM THE CHROMOSPHERE TO THE CORONA.

THE NATIONAL RESEARCH COUNCIL S DECADAL SURVEY PANEL RECOMMENDED THAT NASA LAUNCH THE DEFORMATION, ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE, AND DYNAMICS OF ICE (DESDYNI) RADAR AS A TIER 1 MISSION. IN THE FY12 BUDGET, HOWEVER, MUCH OF THE FUNDING WAS REMOVED AND THE LIDAR COMPONENT WAS EXPLICITLY CANCELLED. THE MISSION WAS REFORMULATED IN COLLABORATION WITH THE INDIAN SPACE AGENCY (ISRO) TO MEET THE BUDGET GUIDELINES. THE RESULT WAS THE NASA ISRO SYNTHETIC APERTURE RADAR (NISAR) MISSION. THIS TEAM GUIDED A JOINT RADAR- LIDAR DESDYNI MISSION SUCCESSFULLY THROUGH ITS MISSION CONCEPT REVIEW (MCR) WITHIN THE NASA SPECIFIED BUDGET GUIDELINES, BEFORE THE DECISION WAS MADE TO REFORMULATE THE MISSION. IN 2011 AS PART OF THE REFORMULATION, THE FIRST NISAR SCIENCE DEFINITION TEAM (SDT) WAS FORMED. THE NISAR MISSION WILL USE RADAR TO STUDY CHANGE OCCURRING IN THE POLAR ICE SHEETS AND SEA ICE, TO MEASURE THE DEFORMATION OF THE EARTH S SURFACE, AND TO CHARACTERIZE GLOBAL ECOSYSTEMS. IT WILL ADVANCE OUR KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF CRITICAL EARTH SCIENCE QUESTIONS PERTAINING TO IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, ESPECIALLY SEA-LEVEL RISE AND CHANGES TO THE SEA-ICE COVER; NATURAL HAZARDS, ESPECIALLY EARTHQUAKES, VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS, AND LANDSLIDES; AND THE EFFECTS OF CHANGING CLIMATE AND LAND USE ON TERRESTRIAL ECOSYSTEMS. THE MISSION ALSO WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW APPLIED RESEARCH AND APPLICATIONS, SUCH AS MONITORING SUBSURFACE FLUID FLOW AND ENGINEERED CARBON SEQUESTRATION; FOREST AND AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS MANAGEMENT; DISASTER RESPONSE AND RECOVERY EFFORTS; AND MONITORING MAJOR MOUNTAIN GLACIERS AND ASSOCIATED WATER, DISASTERS, AND OTHER APPLICATIONS.

VALIDATION AND APPLICATION OF OCO-2 DATA IN THE NORTHEASTERN UNITED STATES URBAN AREAS REPRESENT A KEY TARGET FOR OCO-2 SCIENCE. WE PROPOSE TO VALIDATE OCO-2 DATA, WITH PARTICULAR FOCUS ON THE URBAN-RURAL GRADIENTS OF XCO2 IN THE NORTHEASTERN US, AND TO DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE METHODS FOR DETERMINING URBAN CO2 EMISSIONS USING OCO-2 DATA. ANALYZING OCO-2 DATA IN AN URBAN DOMAIN IS CHALLENGING, ESPECIALLY FOR CITIES CONTAINING, AND SURROUNDED BY, SIGNIFICANT VEGETATION. THE ENHANCEMENT OF XCO2 IN THE "URBAN DOME" IS 2-10 PPM, AND EVEN IN DENSELY POPULATED REGIONS, THE DAILY EXCHANGE OF CO2 FROM VEGETATION EQUALS OR EXCEEDS FOSSIL FUEL EMISSIONS. THE NORTHEAST US, A HEAVILY VEGETATED, DENSELY POPULATED URBAN-RURAL DOMAIN WITH A UNIQUE, COMPREHENSIVE CO2 OBSERVATION NETWORK, OFFERS A SCIENTIFICALLY AND LOGISTICALLY COMPELLING LOCUS FOR VALIDATION OF OCO-2 DATA AND FOR DEVELOPING INVERSE MODELING FRAMEWORKS TO USE OCO-2 FOR DETERMINING URBAN EMISSIONS IN LESS DATA-RICH ENVIRONMENTS AROUND THE GLOBE. THE VEGETATED LANDSCAPE OF THE NORTHEAST US IS MORE HETEROGENEOUS, WITH LOWER REFLECTIVITY, AND HAS A MORE ACTIVE BIOSPHERE WITH MUCH GREATER INFLUENCE ON CO2 FLUXES, THAN IN LOS ANGELES, THE OTHER MAJOR SITE FOR URBAN VALIDATION OF XCO2 FROM OCO-2. HAVING A VALIDATION REGION IN THE NORTHEASTERN US TARGETS ESSENTIAL CHALLENGES FOR INVERSE MODELING OF URBAN EMISSIONS USING OCO-2 SATELLITE DATA. OUR PROPOSED WORK WILL PROVIDE TO THE OCO-2 INSTRUMENT TEAM DIRECT ASSESSMENT OF THE XCO2 GRADIENTS ACROSS THE URBAN DOMAIN,TRACEABLE TO WMO STANDARDS, USING SURFACE MEASUREMENTS, TOTAL COLUMN MEASUREMENTS OF XCO2 USING TWO BRUKER EM27SUN FTIR SYSTEMS AT SEVERAL SITES, DATA FROM TWO PANDORA UV-VIS SPECTROMETERS, AND LIDAR DATA. ALL OF OUR GROUND-BASED SENSORS ARE COMPACT AND MOBILE, WHICH PROVIDES SPATIAL FLEXIBILITY FOR THE VALIDATION. PROJECT DELIVERABLES INCLUDE (1) ASSESSMENT AND VALIDATION OF THE CAPABILITY FOR OCO-2 TO ACCURATELY RESOLVE REGIONAL SCALE GRADIENTS OF XCO2 IN A MAJOR URBAN DOMAIN USING OUR NETWORK OF SOLARTRACKING FTSS AND LIDARS, INCLUDING RESULTS FROM TEMPORARY DEPLOYMENTS DIRECTLY ON OCO-2 TRACKS; (2) BASIC DATA FOR REFINEMENT OF AEROSOL CORRECTIONS FOR OCO-2 MEASUREMENTS VIA VERTICAL PROFILES OF AEROSOLS BY LIDARS AND TOTAL AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH MEASURED BY THE PANDORA UV-VIS SPECTROMETER; (3) ACCURATE REGIONAL CO2 EMISSIONS ESTIMATES BY COMBINING GROUND-BASED SURFACE AND COLUMN DATA WITH OCO-2 XCO2 DATA IN A DATA-MODEL INVERSION FRAMEWORK; (4) IMPROVED CHARACTERIZATION OF URBAN VEGETATION COVER AND ACTIVITY AS NEEDED FOR OCO-2 VALIDATION AND FOR THE TOTAL URBAN CARBON BUDGET; THIS WORK INCLUDES USE OF HIGHLY SELECTIVE OCO-2 FLUORESCENCE DATA; AND (5) DEVELOPMENT OF A GENERALIZED FRAMEWORK TO DERIVE URBAN/REGIONAL SCALE EMISSIONS FROM CITIES AND ASSESS THE CAPABILITY OF OCO-2 DATA ALONE TO QUANTIFY CO2 EMISSIONS IN DATA-POOR REGIONS. TAKEN AS A WHOLE, OUR PROPOSED VALIDATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF A MODEL-DATA INVERSION FRAMEWORK WILL PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE BASIS FOR QUANTIFYING URBAN EMISSIONS, FILLING MAJOR GAPS IN EXISTING URBAN VALIDATION EFFORTS FOR OCO-2 AND PROVIDING CRITICAL NEW INSIGHTS FOR A REGION THAT INCLUDES SIGNIFICANT BIOGENIC AND ANTHROPOGENIC CONTRIBUTIONS.

doc.ContractDescription: THIS PROPOSAL IS TO ESTABLISH THE THEORETICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF ELECTRON HOLES GENERATED IN THE SOLAR WIND AND IN PLANETARY MAGNETOSPHERES BY THE PASSAGE OF UNMAGNETIZED BODIES, AND TO DISCOVER IF THE PLASMA DATA FROM NASA MISSIONS SUCH AS ARTEMIS AND WIND SHOW COMPELLING EVIDENCE THAT SUCH HOLES EXIST. A NEW INSTABILITY MECHANISM, ASSOCIATED WITH THE PLASMA WAKES OF UNMAGNETIZED BODIES IN THE SOLAR WIND, HAS RECENTLY BEEN IDENTIFIED. IT CAUSES THE FORMATION AND GROWTH OF ELECTRON HOLES. THEY HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED BY LARGE-SCALE PIC SIMULATIONS, AND THEIR GROWTH RATE CALCULATED BY SEMI-ANALYTIC THEORY. IT IS THEREFORE PREDICTED THAT THE PLASMA WAKE OF A FAST-MOVING BODY SHEDS A SHOWER OF SMALL ELECTRON HOLES THAT MIGHT BE OBSERVABLE FEATURES IN THE HELIOSPHERE AND PERHAPS IN PLANETARY MAGNETOSPHERES. A SECOND CLASS OF ELECTRON HOLES REMAINS NEAR THE WAKE AXIS AND GROWS TO LARGE AMPLITUDE, EVENTUALLY DISRUPTING THE ION BEAMS THAT ARE CHARACTERISTIC OF THE WAKE. THESE LARGE-AMPLITUDE HOLES, THOUGH FEWER IN NUMBER AND SLOWER MOVING, HAVE A PREDOMINANT EFFECT ON THE WAKE PLASMA AND ARE THE CONTROLLING MECHANISM OF THE FAR-WAKE ION DYNAMICS. THEY ARE CERTAINLY OBSERVABLE IF ENCOUNTERED BY SPACECRAFT. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO ESTABLISH THE DYNAMICAL MECHANISMS THAT GOVERN THESE DIFFERENT CLASSES OF ELECTRON HOLES; TO CALCULATE THEORETICALLY THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THEIR POTENTIAL DEPTH, VELOCITY-WIDTH, AND SPATIAL FORM, BASED UPON THE DRIFT DE-ENERGIZATION GROWTH MECHANISM; AND TO SEARCH FOR EXPERIMENTAL OBSERVATIONS THAT PROVE OR DISPROVE THEIR PRESENCE IN THE SOLAR WIND AND LUNAR WAKE.
doc.MajorAgency: ELECTRON HOLE INSTABILITIES IN THE PLASMA WAKE OF
doc.MajorFundingAgency: ELECTRON HOLE INSTABILITIES IN THE PLASMA WAKE OF

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF DRAGON VOICE REGNITION TRAINING FOR MULTIPLE VA'S WITHIN VIS6
8503678900!MOUNTING BASE,ELECT

THIS PROPOSAL IS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF 0.5 ARC-SECOND ADJUSTABLE GRAZING INCIDENCE X-RAY OPTICS FROM THE CURRENT TRL 3 TO HIGHER TECHNOLOGY READINESS LEVELS, AS NECESSARY TO SUPPORT THE SMART-X MISSION CONCEPT. OUR WORK WILL ADVANCE THE OPTICAL SYSTEM TRL BY INCORPORATING THE DEVELOPMENT OF 0.25 ARC-SECOND, MULTIPLE X-RAY SHELL ALIGNMENT AND MOUNTING, DEVELOPING FLIGHT-LIKE MOUNTING, AND DEMONSTRATION OF MEETING THE VIBRO-ACOUSTIC ENVIRONMENT OF LAUNCH. WE WILL BUILD UPON OUR PLANNED TRL 4 DEVELOPMENT (PLANNED SEPT 15) BY X-RAY TESTING A MULTIPLE X-RAY SHELL SYSTEM. IN ADDITION, WE WILL INITIATE THE DEVELOPMENT AND INDUSTRY DISCUSSIONS TO INCREASE THE SIZE OF THE ADJUSTABLE MIRRORS FROM THEIR PRESENT 10 CM X 10 CM (LIMITED BY OUR COATING CHAMBER) TO FULL SIZE (~ 20 CM X 20 TO 40 CM), MAKING USE OF INDUSTRY CAPABILITIES. WE WILL ALSO CONTINUE REAL-TIME LIFETIME TESTING OF PIEZOELECTRIC TEST MIRRORS IN A SPACE-LIKE ENVIRONMENT (VACUUM, RADIATION, SPACECRAFT SURVIVAL TEMPERATURES, ETC.) BEGUN EARLIER, TO ACCRUE LONG TERM DATA ON THIN FILM PIEZOELECTRIC PERFORMANCE.
doc.MajorAgency: DEVELOPMENT OF 0.5 ARC-SECOND ADJUSTABLE GRAZING I
